Ian Badcoe wrote:

>At 20:21 11/10/2004, you wrote:
>  
>
>>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>>    
>>
>>>inspired by nature.  In nature, not all parts of a chromosome exhibit equal
>>>mutation rates.
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>See my reply to Yuri!
>>    
>>
>
>I think this is different (and maybe thus different from what you want to 
>look at right now).
>  
>
Ok to clarify, Yuri suggested meta-params on each genome, and you are 
talking about an even finer level of granularity with meta-parameters on 
each gene or group of genes (module).

>Sorry, there's three related questions:
>
>1) for a given problem domain what are the best parameters
>2) for the general case what are the best parameters
>         (note that these are both questions about configuring the system 
>from outside)
>3) can we make the system select its own parameters for the current problem
>
>To my mind, it is always a failing when an evolving technique has external 
>configuration parameters which must be tweaked by the user before it 
>works.
>
With some arm twisting I could come around to this idea :) ok but you 
should distinguish between params that need adjusting to make the system 
work, and params that can be pretty much fixed and made concrete within 
the search algorithm because they are applicable to all searches. In 
NEAT we all tend to use low 'add node' and 'add connection' rates and a 
high weight mutation rate, it seems to work well for all the problems we 
have seen to date, yeh we teak them a bit but the system still works 
without the tweaking.

>  So I guess I was straying into the area of 3, whereas you were 
>looking at 1...
>  
>
Indeed. Also consider that the optimal search params may be different at 
different stages of a search.

>
>I take your point about getting carried away (it's always my first reaction 
>to an area of research to go "ah!  but what bout these 17 other related 
>areas...") 
>
Hey it's all food for though - that's what we're here for right. 
Apologies for any negative vibes eminating from my emails yesterday :)

>but I'm not sure adding a mutability to each gene is quite the 
>same as adding a lot of global parameters (it's more like adding one 
>meta-parameter -- it is only one "concept", but implemented separately on 
>each gene)...  But it probably is for a different question from the one you 
>wanted to look at :)
>  
>
My main concern really is that the meta-params would drift and greatly 
reduce the effectivness of a search - see my previous reply (to Ken).

Colin
